Though preparation of HFY-2223tz from halogenated olefins is theoretically effective, it remains great challenges for dehydrohalogenation from halogenated olefins, limiting the detailed knowledge. Here, we established a facile investigation to explore the gas-phase dehydrochlorination reaction of 2‑chloro-3,3,3-trifluoropropene (HCFO-1233xf) over various halides (Na, K, Rb, Cs) supported active carbon (AC) catalysts. The CsF was concluded as the optimal active component with best dehydrochlorination selectivity and conversion of HCFO-1233xf. The CO2-TPD results illustrated that dehydrochlorination of HCFO-1233xf proceeded through E1cB mechanism. Mechanism study revealed the evolution of side-products including (Z/E)-1,3,3,3-tetrafluoropropylene, 2,3,3,3-tetrafluoropropylene, (Z/E)-1‑chloro‑3,3,3-trifluoroproene, and 3,3,3-trifluoroprop-1-ene, etc. However, observable deactivation of CsF catalyst was noticed, which, according to combined XRD and XPS results and density functional theory (DFT) calculations, was attributed to the F/Cl exchange between HCFO-1233xf and catalyst, leading to rapid fluorine consumption. This work thus provides basic knowledge about heterogeneous catalytic synthesis of HFY-2223tz from dehydrohalogenation of halogenated olefins. Graphical abstract Synopsis: 2-chloro-3,3,3-trifluoropropene (HCFO-1233xf) can be highly selectively dehydrochlorinated over CsF/AC-F to generate 3,3,3-trifluoropropyne, however, the rapid deactivation of which resulting from the fluorine-chlorine exchange of HCFO-1233xf with CsF should be the most important issues need to be addressed in the future study. Image, graphical abstract Keywords 3,3,3-Trifluoropropyne 2-Chloro-3,3,3-trifluoropropene Dehydrochlorination Alkali halides Fluorine/chlorine exchange Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Recently, increasing concerns about ozone depletion and global warming lead to growing attention on the development of novel environmentally friendly materials. In view of the fluorocarbon refrigerants, to meet the minimization of ODP (Ozone depleting potential) and GWP (Global warming potential), four ‘generations’ including chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs), hydrochlorofluorocarbons (HCFCs), hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs) and hydrofluoroolefins (HFOs) have been developed. High reactivity of the C=C double bonds result in short atmospheric lifetimes and low GWP values for HFOs, which have been the most environmental-friendly alternatives to date. However, some application fields of HFOs are limited, especially partial physical properties hinder their near-drop-in replacement for substances like HFC-134a [1]. Moreover, CF3COOH, a phytotoxic strong organic acid, has been reported as a constant degradation product of ‘CF3CF=’-containing HFOs (e.g., 2,3,3,3-tetrafluoropropylene (HFO-1234yf)), causing significant secondary pollution [2–4]. As a consequence, 3,3,3-trifluoropropyne (HFY-2223tz) has come into interest as a novel refrigerant with boiling point of -48∼-47 °C [5–9]. As an environmentally friendly CFCs alternative, most recently, the 100-year global warming potential (GWP100) of HFY-2223tz was reported to be 11[10] with negligible ODP [11]. Competitive synthetic routes of HFY-2223tz have been thoroughly reviewed in our previous work [12]. In brief, HFY-2223tz could be synthesized by liquid-phase dehydrochlorination from Z-1-chloeo-3,3,3-trifluoro-1-propene (HCFO-1233zd(Z)) with considerable yield over 83%. 2‑chloro‑3,3,3-trifluoropropene (HCFO-1233xf) and E-1‑chloro‑3,3,3-trifluoroproene (HCFO-1233zd(E)) were recognized as feasible raw materials for gas-phase preparation of HFY-2223tz [13,14]. Considering the problems of large amount use of lye [12,15], high corrosion [16], and difficult disposal of waste [17,18] in liquid-phase method, and the batch-type preparation mode, gas-phase continuous production technology of HFY-2223tz is imperative. However, to our knowledge, effective key technologies of catalyst investigation on gas-phase dehydrochlorination of hydrochlorofluoroolefins (HCFOs) are still insufficient, which are of great challenge. With regard to the dehydrochlorination catalysts for HCFCs, Mao et al. [19] reported that series of alkali halides including NaCl, KCl, CsCl, KF, CsF modified MgO could effectively promote the selectivity of HFO-1234yf from HCFC-244bb dehydrochlorination. Wang et al. [20] found that in CsCl/MgF2, the higher CsCl content provided the higher catalytic selectivity for HCFC-244bb dehydrochlorination. Wang et al. [21] also validated the catalytic activity of NaF for the same reaction. In this work, we investigated and compared the catalytic dehydrochlorination of HCFO-1233xf over supported C-based catalysts by exploring alkali halides composed of NaF, KF, RbF, CsF, KCl, KBr and CsCl. Regarding catalyst supports, three typical active carbons (ACs) were selected to validify the support efficiency. HFY-2223tz has been observed as the main catalytic dehydrochlorination product. However, combined characterization techniques, including Gas Chromatography (GC) and Gas Chromatography-Mass Spectrometer (GC-MS), also revealed the evolution of side-products like HFO-1234yf, HCFO-1233zd(Z/E), 3,3,3-trifluoroprop-1-ene (HFO-1243zf), and (Z/E)-1,3,3,3-tetrafluoropropylene (HFO-1234ze(Z/E)), and others. Possible reaction pathways of notable products were established through density functional theory (DFT) calculations. Although issues, mainly referring to short catalyst life, still need to be addressed by further fine catalyst design, this work proved the validation of catalytic dehydrochlorination as an efficient strategy to prepare HFY-2223tz. Finally, according to experimentally observed F/Cl exchange between HCFO-1233xf and alkali metal fluorides, deactivation mechanism of CsF-based catalysts in system was computed, for which the regeneration potential was thus suggested. 2 Experimental section 2.1 General catalyst preparation Three different ACs as the supports of the catalysts were purchased from Osaka Gas Chemistry Co., Ltd. (coconut shell AC, AC-J), and Fujian Xinsen carbon Co., Ltd. (wooden AC, WAC-F; coconut shell AC, AC-F) respectively. Prior to catalytic reactions, particle diameters of all ACs were screened out as 4 mm. The target catalysts were impregnated by an aqueous solution of NaF (>99%, Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd.), KF (99.0%, Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co., Ltd.), RbF (99.1%, Alfa Aisha (China) Chemical Co., Ltd.), CsF (99.0%, Shanghai Xianding Biotechnology Co., Ltd.), KCl (>99.5%, Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd.), KBr (99.9%, Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd.), CsCl (99.9%, Shanghai Macklin Biochemical Co., Ltd.) at room temperature, respectively, followed by slowly stirring and standing in air over 6 h, drying at 100 °C in a hot air oven for 12 h. Before reaction, all catalysts were dried at 150 °C in nitrogen for 6 h, and finally calcined at 350 °C in the atmosphere of N2 for 12 h. The content of alkaline metal salt in the solution was adjusted to giving the calculated loading of 45.0 wt.% for metal salt. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations Surface areas of the samples were determined by nitrogen adsorption isotherms on a BELSORP-max instrument in static measurement mode (via BET equation) at 77 K. Before the measurements, the samples were degassed at 423 K for 15 h under vacuum. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the prepared samples were measured on a Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.540 Å). The elemental analysis of the fresh catalyst was carried out on a scanning electron microscope (SEM, JOEL JSM-7500F) at an accelerating voltage of 15 kV equipped with an X-ray energy spectrometer (EDS) attachment. The XPS patterns of the spent catalysts were measured on an X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (Thermo fisher Scientific K-Alpha+) at 72 W using Mono Al Kα X-rays as the excitation source. Temperature programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD) and carbon dioxide (CO2-TPD) were performed on AutoChem1 II 2920 instruments, where MS data was recorded with Hiden QIC-20. For pure ACs, a sample of 100 mg was treated under He gas at 200 °C for 2 h, then cooled to 50 °C and saturated with NH3/CO2 (10% in He) for 120 min. Residuary NH3/CO2 was eliminated by flushing the sample under He gas at for 60 min. The sample was heated in the He flow from 50 to 700 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. The amount of off-gas desorbing from the sample was detected by a thermal conductivity detector. For the supported catalysts, similar process was carried out to determine the CO2-TPD results, of which the max desorbing temperature was 650 °C. Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) was performed on a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS20 spectrophotometer. 2.3 Catalytic reaction The dehydrochlorination of HCFO-1233xf (99.96%, provided by Beijing Yuji Science & Technology Co., Ltd.) was performed in a continuous plug-flow fixed-bed reactor at atmospheric pressure. Before the entrance of gas flow into reactor, a preheating furnace was equipped with temperature of 150 °C. The Monel 316 reactor was inserted into a cylindrical furnace equipped with a temperature programmer. A thermocouple well reached the central portion of the reactor. The 3-4 mm catalyst (10 mL) was pretreated in N2 before reaction. Gas flow rate of feed was regulated by a mass flow controller. In addition, 10 mL/min N2 flow was simultaneously injected. The gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) of the feed was 82.5 h- 1. After reaction, the product gas was passed through water to trap acid gases, then analyzed by GC (Aglient 8890) equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID) and a DB-VRX capillary column (60 m × 320 μm × 1.8 μm). Additionally, a GC–MS (Thermo Scientific TSQ-9000) instrument with a scan range of m/z 15-600 was further employed to precisely confirm the structure of the gas-phase products, of which an Inert Cap1 capillary column (60 m × 250 μm × 1.5 μm) was equipped. The conversion of HCFO-1233xf and product selectivity were defined as follows: HCFO-1233xf conversion = 1 - GC area ( % ) of detectable HCFO − 1233 xf in off gas . Product selectivity = GC area ( % ) of target product / HCFO − 1233 xf conversion . 2.4 Computations To understand the molecular characteristics in system, all molecular structures were optimized at M06-2X [22]/def2-TZVP level by using Gaussian 16 program [23]. Possible reaction pathways of HCFO-1233xf were established and calculated under the same level, combined with frequency computations to confirm each stationary point to be either an intermediate or a transition structure. Intrinsic reaction coordinate (IRC) calculations for typical transition states (TSs) were computed to verify the correctness of each pathway [24,25]. The steric effects and Electrostatic potential (ESP) [26] were analyzed through Multiwfn program [27] and visualized by VMD [28], where energy decomposition analysis of EDA-SBL was carried out to quantify the steric energy. Hirshfeld atomic charge analyses [29] were performed through Multiwfn program as well. In this work, F/Cl exchange reaction has been recognized as the dominant factor to deactivate the CsF/AC-F catalyst. This process was further reinforced by the DFT calculations conducted using CASTEP module [30] in the Material Studio program. The generalized gradient approximation with Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof electron exchange-correlation functional (GGA-PBE) [31–33] was adopted. One special Γ-centered k point meshes were used for the Brillouim zone integration. The stable point was identified by the conjugate gradient method until the forces acting on each ion were smaller than 0.03 eV/Å. The energy criterion for optimization convergence of the electron density was set at 10- 5 eV/atom. For energy determination, the energy criterion convergence of the electron density was set at 5 × 10- 7 eV/atom, and the cut-off energy was set as 370.0 eV. TS structure was calculated by using the complete LST/QST method [34] and verified by NEB method. The optimized bulk equilibrium lattice constant of CsF was a = b = c = 6.139 (close to the reported data: a = b = c = 6.008). The exposed (1 1 0) side of CsF was applied for research, and a 3 × 4 super-cell with the vacuum space of 15 Å was employed. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic test, and characterization of the fresh catalysts 3.1.1 Catalytic test According to our thermodynamic calculations (Table S1), the dehydrochlorination of HCFO-1233xf to HFY-2223tz was an endothermic equilibrium process favored by increasing temperature. In Table S1, we noted that the results of △H and △G calculated by two high-level composite methods of CBS-QB3 [35], and Gaussian-4 theory (G4 theory) [36] were reliable with deviations less than 0.51 kcal/mol. Based on these, as temperature functions, the equilibrium yields of HCFO-1233xf dehydrochlorination was calculated (Fig. S1) to increase with increasing temperatures. Some blank experiments (pure active carbon as catalyst) were operated under the same conditions, and the yields of HFY-2223tz were below 0.2% (Table S2). Therefore, a highly active catalyst was essential for the catalytic dehydrochlorination in system. For the supported catalysts prepared by impregnation method, the selection of support is the prerequisite for high efficiency catalyst. Combined FT-IR, XPS, BET, CO2-TPD and NH3-TPD analyses (Fig. S2 and Table S3) and catalytic performance evaluation (Table S4) for three active carbons (ACs) have been carried out. AC-J and WAC-F were recognized to present certain surface acidity and large porosity parameters, providing favorable conditions for the adsorption of oxygen-containing groups on the catalyst surface. Therefore, on a basis of high yield and selectivity of HFY-2223tz, AC-F was explored to establish viable research protocols for loading metal halides on the catalysts for further catalysis study. A series of AC-based alkali metal halides catalysts were tested for the dehydrochlorination of HCFO-1233xf, where NaF, KF, RbF, CsF, KCl, KBr and CsCl were included. The selectivity of HFY-2223tz and the conversion of HCFO-1233xf were shown and compared in Fig. 1 . For the selectivity (Fig. 1(a)), notably, all alkali metal fluorides could effectively promote the dehydrochlorination of HCFO-1233xf. The selectivity of gas-phase catalytic preparation of HFY-2223tz on different AC-supported catalysts decreased in the order of CsF/AC-F (87.84%) > KF (59.49%) > RbF (23.46%) > NaF (10.51%). The poor selectivity of HFY-2223tz on RbF/AC-F might be ascribed to its great moisture adsorption (as discussed latter), leading to large amounts of side reactions. In contrast, other halides-supported catalysts, including KCl, KBr, and CsCl, presented invalid selectivity for HFY-2223tz (less than 7%) at 400 °C. With temperature increasing to 450 °C, the selectivity of HFY-2223tz on all alkali metal fluorides-based catalysts significantly decreased. From Fig. 1(b), overall, all catalysts gave effective rising to conversion of HCFO-1233xf at 400-450 °C. Over KCl/AC-F and CsCl/AC-F, the conversion of HCFO-1233xf were less than 4%, while all alkali metal fluorides imparted obvious catalytic effects on conversion of HCFO-1233xf, among which, the conversion on catalysts at 450 °C ranked in the sequence: RbF (67.29%) > CsF (23.77%) > KBr (19.32%) > NaF (10.00%) > CsCl (3.86%) > KF (3.42%) > KCl (0.63%). Note that high conversion of HCFO-1233xf on KBr/AC-F was attributed to the formation of 2‑bromo-3,3,3-trifluoropropene. Clearly, like metal cations, the halide anion also significantly determined the catalytic performance of HCFO-1233xf. Moreover, according to the hard-soft-acid-base (HSAB) principle[37–39], F− is a harder base than Cl−, so the affinity of the former for binding to hard acid is higher than the latter. Therefore, the addition of alkali metal Cs+ can decrease the surface chemical hardness of catalyst, giving the highest dehydrochlorination activity for HCFO-1233xf. The dehydrochlorination yields of chemicals were also monitored in Fig. 1(b) (solid lines). As discussed above, the dehydrochlorination was endothermic, for which the higher temperature was more favorable. With CsF/AC-F and RbF/AC-F as catalysts, great yields of HFY-2223tz reached up to 5.76% and 5.86% at 400 °C, respectively, achieving 86.93% and 88.39% of the theoretical yields according to the results in Fig. S1. When the temperature further increased to 450 °C, HFY-2223tz yields of 13.49% and 12.94% were achieved on CsF/AC-F and RbF/AC-F, respectively, realizing 92.40% and 88.64% of the theoretical yields. On a basis of the high yield of HFY-2223tz and atomic utilization (selectivity to HFY-2223tz) in system, CsF/AC-F was determined as the optimal dehydrochlorination catalyst. Subsequently, the stability of CsF/AC-F for dehydrochlorination of HCFO-1233xf was investigated within 480-min time scale at 400 °C and 450 °C, respectively (Fig. 2 ). It can be seen that, with the prolongation of reaction time, the selectivity of HFY-2223tz at different temperatures tended to be consistent and stable (>80%), while the conversion of HCFO-1233xf rapidly decreased. Comparatively, for HCFO-1233xf at 450 °C, the selectivity of HFY-2223tz would undergo an obvious increase within the first 180 min. As is shown in Table 1 , the low selectivity to HFY-2223tz at the beginning was ascribed to substantial formation of HFO-1234ze(Z/E), which were considered to be generated from the favorable isomerization of HFO-1234yf [40,41] (detailed discussions can be seen in Scheme S1 in Supporting Information). This indicated that serious fluorination of HCFO-1233xf [42–44] on CsF/AC-F was occurred, leading to the rapid consumption and loss of F in the catalyst. When the reaction proceeded after 240 min, the fluorine content in the CsF/AC-F catalyst decreased, and the catalytic reaction efficiency gradually stabilized. Therefore, further exploration of the catalyst deactivation mechanism, resulted from the F/Cl exchange of HCFO-1233xf and CsF, is of great significance for the development of better catalysts design in the future. 3.1.2 Characterization of the fresh catalysts The above studies showed that series of AC-F-supported alkali metal fluoride catalysts presented significant catalytic activity for HCFO-1233xf dehydrochlorination. Therefore, five typical fresh alkali metal halide/AC-F catalysts including NaF, KF, RbF, CsF and CsCl were characterized to understand the relationship between catalytic performance and physicochemical characteristics of different catalysts. The wide-angle XRD patterns of these typical fresh catalysts were shown in Fig. 3 (i). The standard profiles (presented as dots) of NaF (PDF #36-1455), KF (PDF #36-1458), RbF (PDF #22-0886), CsF (PDF #15-0759) and CsCl (PDF #05-0607) were included as a reference. As can be seen from Fig. 3(i), except CsF/AC-F and RbF/AC-F, all detected diffraction peaks presented the corresponding pure phase of NaF, KF or CsCl, and were in great consistence with the standard peaks, respectively. No diffraction peaks assigned to CsF were observed, where only a wide peak within the 2θ region of 20-30° was found. This might be attributed to the fine particle sizes of supported CsF, implying a homogeneous dispersion of CsF [45] in the AC-F pore channels via an impregnation method, leading to weak diffraction intensity and the pore walls was in an amorphous state. Meanwhile, regarding RbF/AC-F, probably both RbF and oxidized Rb were obtained, where impurities influenced the X-ray diffraction. It can be seen that the introduction of alkali metal fluoride generally weakened the reflection intensity owing to a reduced scatter contrast between pore space and walls. In contrast, CsCl/AC-F showed strong and well-shaped diffraction peaks. Fig. 3(ii) showed the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of the freshly prepared catalysts. The isotherm of all catalysts exhibited the type IV isotherm, where H4-type hysteresis loop was recognized in NaF/AC-F, KF/AC-F, RbF/AC-F, and CsCl/AC-F, according to the IUPAC classification, which was indicative of microporosity materials with narrow slit-like pores [46]. In contrast, CsF/AC-F exhibited the H3-type hysteresis loop, which normally implied slit-shaped pores resulting from an aggregation of plate-like particles. The sharp inflection at the partial pressures P/P0 =0.3-1.0 resembled capillary condensation inside the uniform mesopores and was also a function of the pore diameter. Load of NaF, KF and CsCl did not alter the nature of catalyst framework in the AC-F support, whereas, after supporting CsF and RbF over the carbon matrix, the N2 isotherm hysteresis inflexion became less sharp, demonstrating that the pore size of the catalysts becomes less ordered in comparison to that of others. Simultaneously, the opening of the hysteresis loop at a lower P/P0 partial pressure was observed especially with KF/AC-F, RbF/AC-F, and CsCl/AC-F, clearly indicating the confinement of metal salts particles inside the pores. Further, this was also established by the decrease in the BET surface area results of the fresh catalysts (Table 2 ). Pore size analysis was obtained from the adsorption branch of the N2 isotherm using the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda method, which confirmed that catalysts prepared by the traditional wet impregnation method had narrow pore size distribution. Well-defined microporosity resulted in a high surface area up to 853.52 m2g- 1 in NaF/AC-F, which significantly decreased with the addition of KF, RbF and CsF to 443.73, 380.18 and 5.15 m2g- 1, respectively (Table 2). The morphology and elemental distribution of the catalysts were shown in Fig. 4 . The SEM images illustrated that NaF/AC-F, KF/AC-F, CsF/AC-F and CsCl/AC-F samples prepared by impregnation in aqueous conditions presented plate-like macrostructures, while RbF/AC-F showed obvious cluster structures. The surface of AC-F supported NaF, KF and CsCl catalysts had observable crystal particles. In contrast, the surface of CsF/AC-F was smooth, and no significant agglomeration was observed, indicating that CsF had been uniformly dispersed into the carbon matrix, in agreement with above XRD and BET results. Fig. 4(g-h), S3 and Table S5 exhibited the elemental distribution analyses of freshly prepared catalysts of CsF/AC-F and others, respectively. The homogeneous distribution of all cesium salts (including CsF and CsCl) in the fresh samples over AC-F were confirmed by elemental mapping analysis, indicating that the catalysts prepared by impregnation method were successfully loaded. NaF showed a typical concentrated distribution on the AC-F surface due to the poor water solubility, and so did KF. For RbF/AC-F, agglomeration of Rb and F on the AC-F surface could be observed. In addition, the similar distribution of F and C elements in both RbF/AC-F and CsF/AC-F catalysts indicated high affinity of RbF and CsF for carbon, leading to better dispersion. Besides, according to the high molar ratio of oxygen in RbF/AC-F (Table S5), it can be concluded that the agglomeration phenomenon of RbF mainly resulted from its own moisture absorption. The effects of catalyst basicity on the catalytic dehydrochlorination performance were further investigated by characterizing surface basic properties of typical AC-F based alkali metal catalysts through CO2-TPD and depicted in Fig. 5 . Three types of CO2-desorption peaks at ∼125 °C, 125∼200 °C, and 200 °C∼ were observed, corresponding to weak, medium, and strong basic sites. In Fig. 5, basically broad CO2 desorption peaks for NaF/AC-F, KF/AC-F, RbF/AC-F and CsF/AC-F within the range of 124-208 °C were found, indicating the strongest basic property of CsF/AC-F, followed by RbF/AC-F > KF/AC-F > NaF/AC-F. The strong basic sites were further enhanced in CsF/AC-F, as indicated by the appearance of broad desorption peak at 277 °C. Peak strengths in similar trends also established the catalyst basicity strengths. For CsCl/AC-F catalysts, no strong peaks (only with CO2 desorption peaks at 122 °C) were observed and the peak areas were relatively small, indicating fewer basic amounts. The Lewis acidity of alkali metal fluorides (NaF, KF, RbF, CsF) decreased with increasing atomic number, while the basicity increased. Therefore, it is reasonable to conclude that the dehydrochlorination of HCFO-1233xf mainly occurred at the strong basic-sites over strong basic catalysts. 3.2 Characterization of the spent catalysts To gain a deeper insight into the relationship between deactivation behavior and structure of catalysts in the dehydrochlorination of HCFO-1233xf, the spent catalysts after eight-hour reaction at 400 °C were further characterized. Fig. 6 (i) showed the XRD patterns of various AC-F-based catalysts after reaction. The well-resolved diffraction peaks assigned to the MCl phase (M = Na, K, Rb or Cs) were observed in the spent NaF/AC-F, KF/AC-F, RbF/AC-F and CsF/AC-F samples, and the corresponding chlorides were dominant. For CsCl/AC-F, the CsCl were recognized as the main crystal phases before and after the reaction, respectively. This indicates that these samples had been significantly chlorinated during the reaction. Although substantial studies have been exerted on the dehydrochlorination of chlorinated alkanes, this irreversible process brought great challenges to catalyst stability, resulting in severe requirements for catalysts for dehydrochlorination of unsaturated olefins. XPS was also used to characterize the surface composition and the halogenated state of metals in the spent catalysts. As can be seen in Table S6, elements including F, C, O, Cl, and corresponding metals were well detected in all XPS spectra. The presence of the O 1s peak indicated the moisture absorption of these catalysts after exposure to the atmosphere. For the used CsF/AC-F catalyst, the well-resolved peaks of Cl 2p in XPS spectrum in Fig. 6(ii) confirmed the significant fluorine/chlorine exchange behavior on the CsF/AC-F catalyst, that is, the organic molecules containing Cl represented by HCFO-1233xf had an obvious halogen exchange reaction with the F element in the catalyst, resulting in the conversion of CsF to the corresponding CsCl, which is consistent with the XRD results shown in Fig. 6(i). The XPS spectra of Cl 2p orbitals depicted in Fig. 6(iii) indicated the presence of three types of Cl species on CsF/AC-F catalyst after HCFO-1233xf reaction, including the deposition of C-Cl on CsF/AC-F and the formation of Cs-Cl ionic bonds in system[47]. Obviously, combined with the tetrafluoropropene side-products observed in the experiment, it can be concluded that the chlorine of HCFO-1233xf could significantly be exchanged with the fluorine in CsF, resulting in rapid depletion and loss of F content in the catalyst. XPS fitting spectra of C 1s in CsF/AC-F (Fig. 6(iv)) also proved the organic deposition by identifying the peak of C-Cl group. In addition, observation of -CF and -CF3 fitting peaks [48] confirmed this deposition. One of the most common problems of active carbon-based catalysts is catalyst deactivation by carbon deposition, which also possibly contributed to the deactivation of CsF/AC-F, but this effect should be negligible in this work according to the indiscernible weak shoulder peaks assigned to pi->pi* in Fig. 6(iv). 4 Reaction and catalyst deactivation mechanism-DFT study 4.1 Reaction mechanism Above combined experimental results demonstrated the feasibility of catalytic dehydrochlorination of HCFO-1233xf on CsF/AC-F catalyst. In this study, the CO2-TPD (Fig. 5) results revealed that CsF/AC-F had the strongest basicity in system where Lewis acid sites were limited, which presented the most significant dehydrochlorination efficiency. In contrast, the basicity of CsCl/AC-F was very weak, on which the yield and selectivity of HFY-2223tz were negligible. This implied that the basic sites of catalysts played a key role for molecular dehydrochlorination[19]. Actually, over more basic catalyst, the initial interaction between catalyst and the Hβ atom with acidic character becomes strong. The next step is the C-Cl bond cleavage, which could be more strongly dependent on the bond strength. In Fig. 7 (a), the calculated atomic charge distribution of HCFO-1233xf exhibited that the charge density of F in the -CF3 group is 3.5 time more negative than that of Cl in the Cα atom. The charge density of Hβ is among +0.057 to +0.062. Therefore, the F atom is more strongly interactive with acidic sites than Cl atom rather than basic sites, and the dehydrochlorination process would be dominating over more basic catalyst due to low bond strength of C-Cl. In general, the gas-phase catalytic dehydrochlorination mainly depends on the substrate and catalyst through carbonium-ion mechanism (E1) or H-C-C-X simultaneously eliminating mechanism (E2). E1 acts on substrates bearing α-leaving group with higher basicity over acid catalyst, while E2 is favored on substrates bearing β-H with high acidity over base catalyst [49,50]. Besides, dehydrochlorination can also occur on strong basic catalysts through carbanion-mechanism (E1cB) [51,52]. Based on the acid-base characteristics of the above different catalysts and their catalysis performance, it is reasonably accepted that the gas-phase dehydrochlorination of HCFO-1233xf well occurred via E1cB mechanism over CsF/AC-F catalyst that presented very strong basic sites. This usually takes place in systems with strong basic centers-H interaction and weak acidic centers-halide interaction [50]. Unfortunately, there are only few studies involving with the E1cB mechanism. Fig. 7(a) further exhibited molecular electrostatic potential (MESP) of HCFO-1233xf. It is worth noting that the positive ESPs and charge density of Hβ atoms were in the order: H2 > H1. ESP maxima tend to be the favorable sites for a nucleophilic attack. Therefore, this made it difficult for HCFO-1233xf to undergo anti-coplanar elimination reaction, where, consistent with the experimental results, harsh conditions and better catalyst design are required. In this study, HFY-2223tz was the main product from HCFO-1233xf. Small molecule products, including HFO-1243zf, HCFO-1233zd(E), and HFO-1234ze(Z/E), HFO-1234yf, etc., also significantly evolved during the catalytic reaction, which should be released from the cleavage, isomerization, and fluorination, etc., of HCFO-1233xf molecule. In Fig. 7(b), possible reaction pathways of main side-products formation were established through DFT calculations. As can be seen, HCFO-1233xf could produce HFY-2223tz by direct dehydrochlorination with an energy barrier of 79.79 kcal/mol. For the isomerization of HCFO-1233xf to HCFO-1233zd(E), it started from hydrogen migration to produce IM3-1 with corresponding Gibbs free energy changes (△G) of 79.00 kcal/mol, and then, HCFO-1233zd(E) could be formed via Cl-migration by passing through TS3-2 (△G = 23.41 kcal/mol). Besides, in the presence of superficial OH radical, the IM2-1 radical could be easily formed with a barrier of △G = 44.54 kcal/mol, and HFO-1243zf could be further generated by withdrawing hydrogen from H-O-Cl with a barrier of △G = 47.26 kcal/mol. The anhydrous conditions in similar system thus should be imperative. Indeed, the side-product HCFO-1233zd(E) could further yield HFY-2223tz with equivalent energy barrier of 79.42 kcal/mol (Fig. 7(c)). Beside, from Fig. 7(c), HCFO-1233zd(E) could transform into HCFO-1233zd(Z) with lower energy barriers (71.86 kcal/mol and 9.85 kcal/mol, respectively) through similar mechanism. Therefore, DFT results suggested that the dehydrochlorination of both HCFO-1233xf and HCFO-1233zd(E) were kinetically hard to occur due to the high energy barrier, which was consistent with the thermodynamic calculation and previous experimental results where the reaction could be activated only at high temperatures. However, in contrast with HCFO-1233xf, HCFO-1233zd(E) was computed to be slightly easier to generate HFY-2223tz according to its relatively lower Gibbs free energy barrier. As is well known, atoms and molecules occupy certain positions in space. The hindrance, i.e., the steric effect, induced when they are gathered changes the properties including molecular structure, energy, reactivity, and so on [53]. Therefore, energy decomposition analysis (EDA) based on SBL method [54] was further carried out (Fig. 7(d)) to understand the molecular steric effects, where the relative contributions towards total binding energy (E total) from electrostatic (E electrostatic), steric (E steric), dispersion and repulsion energies (E quantum) were investigated. As shown in Fig. 7(d), the greatly negative value of steric energy (E steric) of HCFO-1233xf substantially contributed to the molecular stabilization, while both electrostatic energy and quantum energy were the main driving force for molecular stabilization of HCFO-1233zd(E). By contrast, high E steric value of HCFO-1233zd(E) would effectively hinder its dehydrochlorination activity. Consequently, though HCFO-1233zd(E) has the lower energy barrier for HFY-2223tz production (Fig. 7(c)), the formation of HFY-2223tz from HCFO-1233zd(E) in this reaction system is negligible. 4.2 Catalyst deactivation mechanism As is shown above, the observations of both the tetrafluoropropene products including HFO-1234yf and HFO-1234ze(Z/E), and the CsCl in spent CsF/AC-F catalyst were significant. According to the mechanism of halogen exchange of chlorinated organic compound and metal fluorides (i.e., the Swarts Reaction) [55], we proposed the mechanism of F/Cl exchange between HCFO-1233xf and CsF, which was recognized as the main deactivation mechanism of CsF catalyst, leading to significant loss of F in CsF. Here, the F/Cl exchange mechanism was further established through DFT calculations and was shown in Fig. 8 (a), including important intermediates (IMs) and transition-state (TS) structures. The stable CsF (1 1 0) surface was adopted. HCFO-1233xf adsorbed on the surface with an exothermic energy of -2.69 kcal/mol (IM1 in Fig. 8(a)). With the adsorption of HCFO-1233xf, the Cs-F bond elongated from 3.075 Å (same level) and 2.871 (different level) to 3.092 Å and 2.920 Å, respectively. And the C-Cl bond slightly elongated from 1.718 to 1.720 Å, indicating electron transfer to the Cs+. Next, the C-Cl bond dissociated through the TS with a cleavage energy barrier of 30.51 kcal/mol, and the dissociated Cl was adopted by Cs+ ion. For the TS, the bond distance of Cs-F was 4.141 Å and that of new Cs-Cl was 3.919 Å, and the distance from C to Cl was 1.978 Å. The remained CF3C(·)=CH2 radical bound with F to form HFO-1234yf (IM2). The product HFO-1234yf could desorb to the gas phase easily with an exothermic energy of -9.74 kcal/mol. Meanwhile, the Cl radical offset to the F site (IM3). Fig. 8(b) illustrated the electron density difference diagram of the TS. It can be seen that C atom of -CF3 and the -CCl group lost electrons, and the surrounding differential charge density was shown as blue (blue corresponds to negative value, losing electrons), while -CH2 gained electrons (red corresponds to positive value, gaining electrons). Meanwhile, F atom in CsF catalysts tended to bond with the 2C of HCFO-1233xf by slightly losing electrons, in combination with drawing electrons from CsF. These were in good agreement with the bond changes in Fig. 8(a). The crystal characteristics of CsxFx (original structure) and partially chlorinated CsxFx-1Cl1 samples were further analyzed in Fig. 8(c). Clearly, the band gap of CsxFx-1Cl1 decreased by 0.05 eV as compared with that of the CsxFx, implying that CsxFx-1Cl1 was of less chemical stability, where the electron excitation became easy, and was conducive to further chlorination and accelerate catalyst deactivation. Therefore, for dehydrochlorination of such olefins, the continuous wastage of F in catalyst system was recognized to be easy and dominant. Based on this, we want to stress that the intermolecular fluorine-chlorine exchange reaction of materials (e.g., by transforming CHF3 to CHCl3) may perform significant role in reactivating the deactivated metal fluoride-based catalyst. 5 Conclusions In summary, this work investigated the catalytic dehydrochlorination reaction of HCFO-1233xf over supported carbon-based catalysts. In our reaction system, CsF/AC-F was recognized as the optimal catalyst with best dehydrochlorination selectivity and yield of HFY-2223tz. According to CO2-TPD analysis, the dehydrochlorination of HCFO-1233xf proceeded via E1cB mechanism on strong basic sites of catalysts. Mechanism study revealed the evolution of side-products including HFO-1234yf, HCFO-1233zd(Z/E), HFO-1243zf, and HFO-1234ze(Z/E), and others. However, the appearance of side-products and the deactivation of CsF/AC-F catalyst caused by the fluorine-chlorine exchange between HCFO-1233xf and catalyst should be the most important issues to be addressed in the future study. This study may pave the way for the future replacement of CFCs. CRediT authorship contribution statement Tongyun Zhang: Investigation, Data curation, Writing – original draft, Visualization. coredata.dc:description: 3,3,3-trifluoropropyne (HFY-2223tz) is a novel refrigerant with great physicochemical properties. Though preparation of HFY-2223tz from halogenated olefins is theoretically effective, it remains great challenges for dehydrohalogenation from halogenated olefins, limiting the detailed knowledge. Here, we established a facile investigation to explore the gas-phase dehydrochlorination reaction of 2‑chloro-3,3,3-trifluoropropene (HCFO-1233xf) over various halides (Na, K, Rb, Cs) supported active carbon (AC) catalysts. The CsF was concluded as the optimal active component with best dehydrochlorination selectivity and conversion of HCFO-1233xf. The CO2-TPD results illustrated that dehydrochlorination of HCFO-1233xf proceeded through E1cB mechanism. Mechanism study revealed the evolution of side-products including (Z/E)-1,3,3,3-tetrafluoropropylene, 2,3,3,3-tetrafluoropropylene, (Z/E)-1‑chloro‑3,3,3-trifluoroproene, and 3,3,3-trifluoroprop-1-ene, etc. However, observable deactivation of CsF catalyst was noticed, which, according to combined XRD and XPS results and density functional theory (DFT) calculations, was attributed to the F/Cl exchange between HCFO-1233xf and catalyst, leading to rapid fluorine consumption. This work thus provides basic knowledge about heterogeneous catalytic synthesis of HFY-2223tz from dehydrohalogenation of halogenated olefins.
coredata.dc:title: Comprehensive study on selective dehydrochlorination of 2-chloro-3,3,3-trifluoropropene over carbon-based catalysts and catalyst deactivation
